column11: Train Collision in Kingsburg Kills Vehicle Driver - Torem & Associates
column12:
Train Collision in Kingsburg Kills Vehicle Driver
A train collision in Kingsburg, southeast of Fresno, on April 18 resulted in the death of an SUV driver. The collision happened on the tracks at Golden State Boulevard and Stroud Avenue around 9:00 p.m. The Kingsburg Police Department reported that the train struck the SUV on the tracks and continued going south. The SUV driver died at the accident scene. An investigation is underway to determine what happened to cause the fatal accident and whether the crossing arms were operating at the time.
Railroad Liability in a Train Collision With a Motor Vehicle
In a collision between a train and a motor vehicle, determining the liability of railroad companies can involve examining whether the railroad company adhered to safety regulations and exercised due diligence in maintaining and operating its trains and tracks. Factors such as the functionality of crossing signals and barriers, the conduct of the train operator, and the maintenance of the railroad tracks play crucial roles in establishing liability following a car accident injury or fatality. Additionally, legal considerations might include examining the railroad’s efforts to warn the public of potential dangers and their compliance with federal and state rail safety laws.
Filing a Wrongful Death Claim Against a Railroad or Track Owner
Filing a wrongful death claim against a railroad or track owner following a train collision requires navigating intricate federal and state regulations. To initiate such a claim, it is important to establish the railroad or track owner’s liability by proving negligence or a violation of safety standards that led to the fatal incident. Evidence gathering plays a critical role in this phase, including collecting accident reports, eyewitness accounts, and expert testimonies related to railway safety and operations.
Engaging with an attorney who is experienced in railroad accidents can significantly improve the chances of a successful outcome by ensuring that the legal rights of the deceased’s estate and beneficiaries are effectively represented.
Recovering Compensation by Filing a Wrongful Death Claim in California
In California, filing a wrongful death claim after a train collision allows the decedent’s surviving relatives or estate to seek various types of compensation. These compensatory damages are designed to provide financial relief and acknowledge the intangible losses suffered due to a loved one’s untimely death. The types of compensation that may be recovered include:
- Funeral and burial costs: The family can recover the expenses associated with funeral services and burial or cremation.
- Lost wages plus benefits: Financial support that accounts for the wages and benefits the deceased should have earned had they lived until retirement is recoverable.
- Loss of love, companionship, and support: Monetary recognition is possible for the loss of emotional support, companionship, affection, and guidance the deceased provided.
- Punitive damages: In some cases, if the actions leading to death were particularly egregious, punitive damages may be awarded to punish the wrongdoer and deter similar conduct in the future.
Each of these categories represents a critical component of the total compensation pursued in a wrongful death claim in California, offering a semblance of financial stability and justice for the survivors. However, in California, the train collision claim must be filed within two years, which represents the statute of limitations. Because witnesses move away and evidence can disappear in that time period, enlisting the help of a wrongful death lawyer soon afterward improves the family’s chance at recovering the compensation they deserve.

What Should You Do After a Train Accident in Los Angeles, CA?
A train accident can’t be planned for, but you can be ready for it. Having a train accident checklist can help you stay calm and get things done after an accident. It can help you stay safe and tell you what to do and what not to do. This concerns not just your well-being but also your right to proper compensation.
When in doubt, give us a call. It would be best if you either wrote down or kept our phone number, (888) 488-1391, with you in case something goes wrong. You aren’t alone after a serious collision. After a train accident, here’s what you should do:
- Call 911 right away to report the crash. Get a copy of the police record or accident report; it will be very important to your case.
- As soon as possible, get medical help to lessen how bad the damage is. Scan results and tests can show injuries inside the body that haven’t shown any immediate signs or symptoms.
- Get the contact information of everyone who saw or was involved in the accident. Include their names, phone numbers, and insurance information. You should also include pictures of their license plates, cars, and any other proof you can find.
- Talk to the insurance company about the facts. You shouldn’t lie about the facts of the fatal accident or take an insurance settlement offer before talking to a lawyer.

Train Accident Statistics
In 2021, 893 people had died in train crashes. This is 20% more than last year. Furthermore, a total of 5,770,811 hospital admissions were not deadly, 4% more than the year before.
The National Safety Council says that between 2020 and 2021, the number of deaths at highway-rail crossings rose by 21%, while the number of deaths in other types of crashes rose by 20%. Out of the 617 deaths, 94% were caused by people who were not supposed to be there. Every year, more than 1,000 train crashes happen. About 2,300 people were hurt, and about 600 of them died.

column11: [02-19-2023] Fatal Crash Involving Train in San Diego, 2 Dead - Arash Law
column12:
A man and a woman are dead following a collision with a train in Fresno County on Sunday, February 19, 2023.
Officers responded just before 3:00 p.m. to a report of a vehicle colliding with a train on East Conejo and South Peach Avenues.

Shortly after, the car and a northbound train collided, killing the driver and the passenger instantly.

The crash remains under investigation.
Fatal Train Crash Statistics
According to the National Transportation Safety Board, pedestrians die in railway accidents more often than in collisions with cars. Faulty warning systems, outdated or absent safety equipment, and dangerous crossings cause the most deadly train accidents.
About every two hours, a train collides with someone or a car. Each year, more than a thousand people are killed in train accidents. There were about 2,300 injuries and 600 fatalities as a result.
Trains are the most effective form of transportation. The skills of the conductors and how frequently repairs are made are factors that affect employee and passenger safety. Passengers are at risk due to their negligence or inadequate shortcuts.
Over 7,200 people have died in US train accidents since 1997. Trains colliding with pedestrians on American railroads are currently the leading cause of fatalities, outpacing all other factors.
Derailments, worn-out tracks, contempt for safety regulations, lax security, and other factors are typically to blame for railway accidents.
What To Do After an Accident
When you get involved in a collision, it is crucial to contact the appropriate authorities immediately. Don’t provide any assumptions when being questioned. Simply tell them what happened.
Even though they had nothing to do with the incident, the victim may nonetheless feel responsible for it. Such behaviors can provide the insurance company with an excuse to reject the claim.
If you formally request it, the relevant authorities must give you a copy of the report. If you’d like us to submit the request for you, please fill out our online form. As soon as we have the report, we’ll get started on your case. Get a free evaluation of your insurance claims right now.
Fresno County Train Accident Lawyers
Most people have taken the subway or another type of public transit at some point. Accidents can still happen even if this is a generally safe and effective means of transportation.
The chance of injury or death in a railway accident is smaller than for many other modes of transportation, yet it is nevertheless present. You might be entitled to compensation if you or a loved one is hurt in a railway accident.
To make sure your accident-related costs, such as medical care, missed income, and pain and suffering, are covered, our legal team will get in touch with your insurance company.
Our Fresno County train accident attorneys advocate for the legal rights of victims injured in train accidents. Our goal is to ensure that you remain focused on your recovery while we pursue compensation on your behalf.
To schedule a free legal consultation, call us at (888) 488-1391 or fill out the “Do I Have A Case?” form online.

column24: East Conejo and South Peach Avenues

column11: 2 killed after train strikes vehicle in Fresno County identified - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO COUNTY, Calif. (FOX26) — Two people were killed Sunday after their vehicle was struck by a train in Fresno County.
According to the California Highway Patrol, officers were called around 2:50 p.m. after learning of the collision near Conejo and Peach Avenues.
Officers say the vehicle went around the railroad crossing bars and was struck by the train.
Both, investigators say, were killed following the collision and were later identified as Jorge Martinez Escalante, 57, and Guadalupe Lopez Boroquez, 57.
Officers say Escalante and Boroquez are married and from Kettleman City.
It’s unknown if drugs or alcohol played a factor in the crash.

column11: Fire, explosions rock Kingsburg after deadly train crash - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
Footage from the scene shows thick black smoke billowing in huge clouds, visible from miles away.
KINGSBURG, Calif. (KFSN) -- A man died in Kingsburg after a freight train hit his semi-truck on Thursday, sparking flames and explosions.
The crash happened on the railway tracks in the area of Sierra and Simpson just off Highway 99.
The resulting blast was so intense that parts of the engine went flying feet away and the safety arm that lowers when a train is approaching was blown off.
The driver of the truck did not survive. The train crew was not injured.
A witness, Mickey P, said he saw the semi-truck on the railway track and the train crossing-arms come down on its hood.
Moments later, the train crashed into the truck, sparking flames and an explosion.
"It was instant, just 'boom'... catastrophic!" Mickey P told Action News.
Footage from the scene shows thick black smoke billowing in huge clouds, visible from miles away.
The police department still doesn't know how or why the semi-truck driver didn't get off the tracks before being hit.
Kingsburg PD says a crash like this is unusual in their town.
They are hoping an eyewitness or cell phone video from the moments leading up to the crash will help them figure out why it happened.
On Friday, railroad crews worked to repair the safety arms that were blown off Thursday night.
The Fresno County Sheriff's Office says unfortunately, the man killed in this crash was burned so badly that it will take some time to identify him through DNA.

column11: Big rig driver killed in fiery crash with train in Kingsburg identified - KMPH
column12:
KINGSBURG, Calif. (FOX26) — A semi-truck driver is dead after crashing into an ongoing train in Kingsburg.
60-year-old Arturo Godinez was killed on Aug. 18th when the big rig he was driving crashed into a moving train.
Kingsburg Police, the Kingsburg Fire Department along with other agencies responded to the collision near Sierra and Simpson Streets Thursday around 8 p.m.
[RELATED]Officials: At least 2 die after planes collide in California
According to a FOX26 viewer, there were several explosions shortly after the crash as the truck went up in flames.
People were asked to avoid the area for hours.
Caltrans was called in to help clear out the railways and say they may be out there for the rest of the night.
It is unknown why the driver did not make the stop as the train was seen going.
[RELATED]2 people dead after their car is found down embankment
It took until December for the sheriff's office to get the DNA results to get confirmation of the identity of the driver.

column11: Truck driver killed in explosive train collision in California - CDLLife
column12:
A truck driver lost his life on Thursday in a crash involving a train that occurred in Kingsburg, California.
The incident occurred around 7 p.m. on Thursday, August 18, at Sierra Street and Simpson Street near Highway 99 in Kingsburg.
Kingsburg: State Route 201 (Sierra/Conejo) CLOSED just east of State Route 99 at RR tracks due to semi vs train, resulting in semi on fire. No ETO pic.twitter.com/r0xzzx1tYS
— Caltrans District 6 (@CaltransDist6) August 19, 2022
“The train was traveling southbound through town and the truck was traveling west. At this point, we don’t know what happened to make him go through the arms,” the Kingsburg Police Department told KSEE.
The crash sparked a massive fire and explosions, producing heavy black smoke visible from miles away.
The truck driver passed away as a result of the crash. His identity has not yet been released.
The cause of the collision remains under investigation.

column11: 1 killed, 1 hospitalized after crash involving train near Dinuba, deputies say - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
TULARE COUNTY, Calif. (KFSN) -- A man has died and a woman is in the hospital after their car crashed into a train near Dinuba.
It happened just before 2 Saturday morning on Avenue 424 west of Road 72.
According to Tulare County sheriff's investigators, the pair were in a Toyota Camry when they crashed into the train, sparking a fire.
The driver, a man in his 20s, died at the scene.
His passenger, a woman in her 20s, was taken to the hospital with minor injuries.
Investigators had Road 424 closed near the crash site for several hours, but it has since reopened to traffic.
It's unknown if alcohol or drugs were a factor in the crash.

column11: No injuries reported after freight train hits car south of Fresno - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (FOX26) — A train hit a car south of Fresno early Wednesday morning.
It happened sometime after 4:00 a.m. along Golden State Blvd. between Central and American Avenues.
Investigators say it is still unknown if the driver drove around the crossing gates which were down.
They say nobody was hurt.
The car was removed from the tracks and the train was allowed to continue after the tracks were inspected for damage.

column11: VIDEO: Truck gets struck by train in Sanger - KMPH
column12:
SANGER, Calif. (FOX26) — A truck driver was hit by an ongoing train in Sanger.
As seen on surveillance video the truck was traveling east on 5th Street near Academy Avenue when it was struck.
[RELATED]DUI driver arrested following a hit and run in Visalia
The truck driver failed to stop, as there are no railroad crossing gates or lights to signal oncoming traffic.
Fortunately, no critical injuries were reported.

column11: Pedestrian hit and killed by Amtrak train in northwest Fresno - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- Police are investigating after a person was hit and killed by an Amtrak train in northwest Fresno on Friday morning.
It happened around 10:30 am near West and Sante Fe Avenues.
Fresno police say the female pedestrian was standing on the tracks when the train collided with her. She died at the scene.
Her name and age have not been released.
Investigators say all safety equipment along the tracks was working as the train approached the crossing.

column11: Semi-truck slams into train in southeast Fresno - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- The California Highway Patrol is investigating after a semi-truck slammed into a train in southeast Fresno Wednesday morning.
Officials say the train was traveling westbound near Jensen and Maple Avenues around 8:30 am on tracks that had no guarded rail crossing.
Railroad crews had set up flares to warn drivers of the crossing train, but the CHP says the truck driver was southbound on Maple Avenue and didn't see the flames.
The truck hit the train and was dragged a few feet west.
Investigators say the truck driver was traveling too fast for fog conditions. Visibility was around 200 feet at the time of the crash.
No one was hurt.
Southbound Maple Avenue is expected to be closed for another hour.

column11: Big rig involved in crash with freight train in thick fog Fresno - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (FOX26) — A big rig was involved in a mishap with a freight train in Fresno Wednesday morning.
The incident happened around 8:30 a.m. at the train tracks that cross Maple Ave. between Jensen and Annadale Avenues.
The track is a sideline used to load and unload at warehouses in the area so the train was not going very fast when the two made contact.
The track is not controlled by crossing arms.
CHP says the train crew placed flares in the roadway because dense fog reduced visibility under 200 feet, but the driver of the truck was unable to avoid hitting the train.
The truck pulling two trailers was blocking the southbound lanes of Maple and the train was blocking both directions.
The train moved off the roadway around 9:30 a.m. and a large tow truck was preparing to remove the big rig.
There were no injuries.

column11: Driver hit by train in Sanger, police say - KMPH
column12:
TOPICS:
Disaster AccidentSangerSANGER, Calif. (FOX26) — Sanger police and Fire responded to 5th Street and Academy Avenue for a vehicle hit by a train.
The train blocked off 5th street, 7th street, and 9th street.
According to Sanger PD, a driver had a slow-speed crash with the train.
The rear side of the car was hit and the driver was taken to the hospital.
The driver's condition is currently unknown.
Drugs and/or alcohol do not appear to be a factor at this time.
This is a developing story and will be updated as we learn more.
column70: SANGER SANGER SANGER SANGER SANGER SANGER

column11: Man hit and killed by train in Merced - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
MERCED, Calif. (KFSN) -- Merced police are investigating after a man was hit and killed by a train on Thursday night.
It happened on the Union Pacific Railroad tracks near G Street and West 16th Street just before 9:30 pm.
Police say the man was walking along the tracks when he was struck by a passing train. He has not yet been identified.
Officials are working to determine why the man was walking near the
It is unknown if drugs or alcohol played a part in the crash.

column11: Two men killed in train crash in southeast Fresno identified - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO, Calif — Two men died after police say they tried to go around train crossing arms in Fresno.
Officers say they were called to Central Avenue near Maple Monday around 10:30 p.m.
Witnesses told police a few cars were successful in going around the crossing arms from the eastbound side, but one car tried to go around the westbound side and was hit by an oncoming Amtrak train.
The driver 27-year-old Noe Maravilla of Fresno and his passenger 21-year-old Juan Ramirez of fresno died in the crash.

column11: 16-year-old boy hit and killed by train in Merced, police say - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- Merced Police say it was near this railroad crossing that 16-year-old Devonea Graham lost his life Saturday afternoon.
Officers say the teen and his two younger siblings were crossing the tracks at P and 24th Streets when Graham was hit by a train.
Not far from that location, Rosalinda Vega lost her 13-year-old son, Vicente Mancera, to similar circumstances in 2019.
This latest tragedy stirring up painful memories.
"Anyone who has not lost a child could never possibly understand the pain and the change that that takes on life," she said.
Vega's son was on his way home from school when the accident happened.
She says the stretch of train tracks along 24th Street isn't blocked off and is easily accessible to children.
It also runs near two schools. She says more needs to be done to keep kids away.
"If we put up a fence to avoid that, then children will be obligated to walk around to come home," she said.
Police say anyone wanting to cross the tracks should do so at designated crossings or use the G Street overpass.
Now as another family grieves the loss of a teenager, Vega says she and another mother are looking to start a support group.
She's also taking matters into her own hands by advocating for more safety measures.
Vega says she is raising money for a fence along the railroad to prevent future tragedy on the tracks.

column11: 5-year-old child killed in train crash while family waited to enter Christmas Tree Lane identified - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
The child was killed after his family's minivan was hit by an Amtrak train as they waited in line to enter Christmas Tree Lane.
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- The Fresno County Coroner's Office has identified the child who was killed in a train crash in central Fresno on Tuesday night as five-year-old Anton Solorio of Fresno.
The family was waiting in line to enter Christmas Tree Lane and their van stopped on the tracks and was later hit by an Amtrak train, killing the child.
Robert Solorio, Anton's father, released a statement to Action News about the family's heartbreaking loss.
We sit here tonight with a void in our hearts. We miss our dear son Anton Isaac Solorio who's precious soul was taken from us so quickly. Such a loving, charming, respectful and caring son, brother, nephew, grandson, friend just to name a few. In the blink of an eye, everything can change. So make the most with those who mean the most. Forgive often and love with all your heart. You may never know when you may not have that chance again.We would like to extend our sincere gratitude and appreciation to all those who have reached out, prayed and donated.
If you want to help the family, you can contribute to their GoFundMe page.
This is a developing breaking news update. Our original story follows below.
Tuesday night was supposed to be a time for joy - the kickoff to Christmas Tree Lane's twinkling lights, holiday music, and wooden reindeer, but the holiday cheer has turned into a memory of pain for one grieving family in Fresno.
A child was killed after a family's minivan was hit by an Amtrak train as the family waited in line to enter the lane.
The crash happened at Shields and Maroa at 5:30 pm.
The impact sent three other family members, including the child's mother, to the Community Regional Medical Center with minor injuries.
The devastating turn of events happened when the family's car got stuck on the tracks while waiting just feet from the entrance to the iconic holiday light display.
The Amtrak train, which had 50 passengers inside, crashed into the stuck car.
First responders arrived and provided aid, but the child died.
None of the Amtrak passengers were injured. The train was headed to Bakersfield and has since continued on with its route.
Investigators are trying to determine how the minivan got stuck on the tracks.
Stunned witnesses shared their shock and grief after helplessly watching the van get stuck on the tracks.
One of them said traffic lining up to enter Christmas Tree Lane on Van Ness Avenue - just feet from the railroad crossing - was backed up for blocks.
The traffic congestion is a known problem for those who visit Christmas Tree Lane every year.

column11: Mother had not cleared the track in deadly train crash, police say - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (FOX26) — Over 24 hours later, a Fresno family is heartbroken following the tragic death of a 5-year-old boy on opening night of Christmas Tree Lane.
On Tuesday, the Fresno Police Department says a family was waiting in line for their turn to take in the lights.
In the van was a family of four: a mother, a grandmother, and two small children.
They were just about to reach the entrance of Christmas Tree Lane when tragedy struck.
Police say the mother thought she had cleared the train tracks, but an investigation shows there was still a big portion of the van in harm's way.
"From the video, from the pictures that we see it looks like just about a foot of the rear end of a 2018 Dodge Caravan was sticking on a southbound track," explained Fresno Police Department Deputy Chief Michael Reid.
As a train raced at more than 70 miles an hour, it crashed into the back of the van, killing 5-year-old Anton Solorio in the backseat on impact.
"Those things going that fast and this was six cars in one locomotive carrying about 70 passengers, it takes a while to stop."
RELATED |Child killed in van hit by train waiting to visit Christmas Tree Lane identified
Anton's mother, grandmother, and 22-month-old brother were taken to a local hospital following the crash with minor injuries.
His brother and grandmother have been released, but his 7-month-pregnant mother remains in the hospital to ensure the baby is okay, according to a close family friend.
FOX26 News went digging through the Federal Railroad Administration records to see how many other crashes there have been at the Shields railroad crossing.
We found there have been 5 other accidents since 2002.
Out of all 6 crashes, three adults have died, with the latest now claiming the life of a child.
"The is a tragedy, it's an avoidable tragedy. Our heart goes out to that family we'll support them any way we can but more importantly, I want to prevent this from happening again," said Reid.
A GoFundMe account has been set up to help with the funeral expenses for Anton.
Click hereto make a donation.

column11: Fresno mourns death of 5-year-old in Christmas Tree Lane train crash - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- A Fresno family was almost to their destination Tuesday night - Christmas Tree Lane - when the back of their minivan was struck by a six-car Amtrak train near the intersection of Shields and Wishon.
RELATED: 5-year-old child killed in train crash while family waited to enter Christmas Tree Lane
The force of the crash killed a 5-year-old boy, identified by the Fresno County Sheriff's Office as Anton Solorio.
On Wednesday, area residents were still in shock, trying to understand what went wrong on the tracks.
"To hear something like this, it's a rip in the fabric of our universe," says John Alden.
Adds Debi Ruud:
"We couldn't even imagine how it can happen."
The cause of the crash is still under investigation.
But Fresno Police say it appears the railroad signals were working at the time and that the train engineer applied the brakes and used the horn.
They believe the boy's mother was driving the van and simply thought she had cleared the tracks when she hadn't.
"It's a tragedy, it's an unnecessary loss of life, and it's something that's absolutely avoidable so we just need to remind motorists about safety," says Fresno Police Deputy Chief Michael Reid.
RELATED: Deadly intersection near Christmas Tree Lane has been site of several other crashes
JD Sanders lives nearby, and is still processing what he saw and heard last night, hoping it never happens again.
"I ran down there and heard the mother screaming and I had to come back to my house because it was too much for me," he says. "It's pretty terrible."
Sanders called 911, and by the time he went back outside, police were everywhere.
The boy's mother, who is pregnant, was brought to the hospital to get checked out.
His grandmother and younger sibling were in the car too and also expected to be ok.
On Wednesday, Valerie Espinoza stopped by the scene to pay her respects to the little boy who passed away.
"I just came to bring some balloons because I felt very bad for the child, you know he's a baby," she said.
She also shared an important reminder for all families.
"Just cherish life because life is so precious."
Fresno Police are reminding everyone that trains pass through the intersection frequently, and that they move fast, and take a long time to stop.
The train was going at approximately 70 miles per hour.
Robert Solorio, Anton's father, released a statement to Action News about the family's heartbreaking loss.
We sit here tonight with a void in our hearts. We miss our dear son Anton Isaac Solorio who's precious soul was taken from us so quickly. Such a loving, charming, respectful and caring son, brother, nephew, grandson, friend just to name a few. In the blink of an eye, everything can change. So make the most with those who mean the most. Forgive often and love with all your heart. You may never know when you may not have that chance again.We would like to extend our sincere gratitude and appreciation to all those who have reached out, prayed and donated.
If you want to help the family, you can contribute to their GoFundMe page.

column11: Child killed in van hit by train waiting to visit Christmas Tree Lane identified - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (FOX26) — A crash between a train and a family's minivan has left one child dead near Christmas Tree Lane in Fresno.
The Fresno County Coroner's Office identified the child as 5-year-old Anton Solorio of Fresno.
The crash happened around 5:30 p.m. on Tuesday on the train tracks on Shields and Wishon.
The Fresno Police Department says the family was waiting in line to drive down Christmas Tree Lane when their minivan got stuck on the tracks.
The van wasn't able to make it off of the tracks in time and was hit by a train.
The child was confirmed dead at the scene, and three other family members were rushed to the hospital.
RELATED |Christmas Tree Lane opens for holiday season in Fresno
Officers say at least one of those family members is the child's mother.
Police say all three received some bruises and cuts, but are expected to be okay.
Both sides of Shields Avenue have been closed, from Maroa Avenue to the train tracks.
Just on the other side of those tracks is the entrance for Christmas Tree Lane at Shields and Van Ness Blvd.
Tuesday marked the opening night of Christmas Tree Lane, so traffic was heavy in the area as families waited in line.
Police believe that traffic jam may have caused the minivan to become stuck on the tracks.
RELATED |Christmas Tree Lane prepares for 100th anniversary, homeowners in overdrive
Investigators are also looking into if the van had any mechanical issues that made it unable to move out of the way.
A GoFundMe account has been set up to help with the funeral expenses forAnton.
If you'd like to donate, you can do so here.

column11: Train derailment near Highway 99: Overturned tank cars removed nearly 24 hours after train derails - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
One of the derailed cars carrying hydrochloric acid, a chemical that can be harmful to humans, leaked as the train came to a crashing halt.
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- California Highway Patrol officers have reopened two of the three northbound lanes on Highway 99 in Tulare County, more than 24 hours after a train derailment shut down the highway.
The derailment happened just before 7 am on Monday, closing a 10-mile stretch of the highway in Goshen for hours.
Crews worked through the night to repair the wreckage left behind after the Union Pacific train derailed, spilling toxic chemicals near Goshen.
Union Pacific officials said six tank cars derailed. One carrying hydrochloric acid, a chemical that can be harmful to humans, leaked as the train came to a crashing halt.
Early Tuesday morning, officials had removed all the overturned cars, and were working to repair the rails.
On Monday night, all three southbound lanes and one northbound lane had reopened to drivers. Travelers inched their way along Highway 99 in Tulare County more than 12 hours after the accident.
By Tuesday morning, a second northbound lane was opened.
The California Highway Patrol had more people on patrol as part of the heavily used freeway heading north is still closed off, and dozens of local and state agencies remain at the crash site.
CHP officials said there were no longer any leaks, and the air quality was good and stable.
Railroad officials said they hope to have the highway fully reopen by the end of Tuesday.
The cause of the derailment is still under investigation.
Click here to see the latest traffic conditions on Highway 99.
column69: The train derailed just before 7 am on Monday, causing a spill of hydrochloric acid and shutting down Highway 99 in Tulare County for hours.

column11: Hwy 99 open as train derailment cleanup continues - KMPH
column12:
GOSHEN, Calif. (FOX26) — Highway 99 has reopened in Tulare County following Monday's train derailment near Goshen.
The Union Pacific southbound mixed freight train derailed six tank cars around 6:30 a.m.
Four of the tankers were carrying butane and two had hydrochloric acid.
There were no injuries or waterways affected, however one tank car was reported to be releasing hydrochloric acid onto the ground.
Hazmat crews from Fresno and Visalia were called out and the highway was closed due to thepossibility of dangerous chemical leaks.
The California Highway Patrol reopened southbound lanes of Highway 99 around 4:30 p.m. Monday and then one northbound lane around 8:00 p.m.
Crews worked through the night to right the overturned tanker cars and then closed the northbound lanes for a short time Tuesday morning to lift the final car.
CHP has reopened two northbound lanes of Hwy 99 but expects to open all lanes by 10:00 a.m. Tuesday.
The closures have caused long delays and traffic congestion between Visalia and Kingsburg as people were rerouted around the derailment.

column11: Man killed after train hits car in Fresno County - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO COUNTY, Calif. (KFSN) -- Authorities are investigating a deadly train accident in Fresno County.
It happened at Golden State Boulevard and Maple Avenue just before 3 pm on Sunday.
A CHP sergeant says witnesses reported that a man driving a car did not stop at a stop sign before starting to cross the tracks.
His car was hit by a Union Pacific train, which the conductor said was going about 30 miles per hour at the time.
First responders removed the victim from the car and tried to revive him, but he died at the scene.
Investigators say it's unknown at this time if drugs or alcohol were involved.
column24: Golden State Boulevard and Maple Avenue

column11: Woman hit and killed by train in central Fresno identified - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
Officers believe the incident is accidental
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- A woman who died after being hit by a train in central Fresno has been identified as 19-year-old Ashley Sanchez.
Police officers were called to Fruit and Ashlan around 11:30 Friday night when they found her body.
At this point, officers believe the incident is accidental.
They say after interviewing the conductor, the train did not have enough time to stop before Sanchez was hit.
An investigation is underway to determine why she was walking so close to the tracks.
The crossing at Fruit and Ashlan has since re-opened.

column11: One person dead after being hit by train in Tulare County - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
TULARE CO., Calif. (KFSN) -- The Tulare County Sheriff's Office says one person was hit and killed by a train in Tulare County Saturday afternoon.
Officials responded to a call around 1:30 p.m. near Highway 99 and Merritt. The fire department arrived at the scene first and confirmed the fatality.
California Highway Patrol is now on the scene and investigating the incident.

column11: SUV collides with train in Selma, 1 dead - KMPH
column12:
SELMA, Calif. — UPDATE: Thursday, August 22, 2019 - The person killed in Wednesday's train vs vehicle crash has been identified as 64-year-old Escolastica Andres of Reedley.
- - -
At least one person was killed when an SUV collided with a train.
It happened Wednesday morning in the area of Golden State and Highland in Selma.
According to officials with Union Pacific, there were two people in the SUV at the time of the collision, one person was killed.
The tracks will remain closed in that area until the investigation is completed.
Officials say the tracks will likely reopen Wednesday afternoon.

column11: Driver tries to beat a train in Fresno, gets hit by train instead - KMPH
column12:
TOPICS:
I (Almost) Got Away With ItFRESNO, Calif. (FOX26) — A driver was sent to the hospital after trying to beat a train in west Fresno.
The man thought that he could beat the train and decided to go for it, according to California Highway Patrol Officer Vic Taylor.
It turns out, the man was not able to beat the train, and his truck was hit by the train instead.
The driver was taken to the hospital, with a fractured hip.
He was the only person in the car, and officers say he was driving without a license.
Drugs and alcohol do not appear to be a factor in the crash, according to CHP.
CHP would like to remind drivers to never try and beat a train.

column11: Driver hit by Amtrak train in Fresno after crossing arm mishap - KMPH
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (FOX26) -- A woman driver and a male passenger are lucky to be alive after getting hit by an Amtrak train while trying to cross the tracks in Fresno.
The driver says the crossing arms lowered at Belmont & Diana, but then raised back up, so she tried to drive through and was hit.
Fresno Police says the driver went to a hospital to get checked out, but was not badly hurt. The male passenger wasn't hurt.
The train ripped the whole front end and bumper off of the white sedan.
The Amtrak train was headed southbound and didn't stop after the crash until it reached the Amtrak station in Downtown Fresno. The train itself had very little damage.

column11: Man hit and killed by train in Northwest Fresno - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- An investigation is underway after a man was hit and killed by a train in Northwest Fresno just after midnight on Friday morning on Ashlan near Fruit.
Police say they found the man dead at the scene.
They say a Burlington Northern Santa Fe train struck the man and was not aware. The train stopped somewhere in Madera after being told what happened.
There were no witnesses at the scene, and police are cautioning others to be aware of their surroundings when approaching train tracks.
"Especially in the evening, if people are wearing dark clothing, we highly recommend do not walk on the train tracks or near the train tracks cause even if you're walking next to them, the trains have such suction when they go by, that they can actually pull you into the train cars as they pass," Lieutenant Jennifer Horsford, Fresno Police said.
The person hit by the train has not yet been identified.
It's not yet known if the incident was intentional or a deadly mistake.

column11: Man killed after being hit by Amtrak train in Southeast Fresno - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- A man has died from his injuries after being hit by an Amtrak train in Southeast Fresno Monday afternoon.
The incident happened at California and East.
Police said the train was traveling southbound when it hit the man on a bike who went around the railroad crossing arms that were activated and down.

column11: Woman dead after train crashes into truck near Madera - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. -- A woman is dead Friday after a train collided with her pickup truck near Madera.
The crash happened around 4:30 p.m. at a rail crossing in the area of Avenue 15 and Road 29. Investigators said the woman tried to get around the rail crossing but instead entered the path of an oncoming train and was hit.
The woman died on scene and officers closed the road during the investigation.
Police said alcohol does not appear to be related.

column11: Truck driver who was nearly hit by train after truck gets stuck on tracks in Atwater speaks out - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
ATWATER, Calif. (KFSN) -- We are now hearing for the first time from the driver of that big rig hit by a train in Atwater earlier this week. Just a day before the crash an Atwater city council member addressed the dangerous intersection.
An abc30insider captured the moment a train smashed through a truck in Atwater. The driver had just seconds to escape.
Ajitpal Batti said he was making a right turn and his truck got stuck in the median
"I don't even remember hearing the train. I was nervous trying to do what I can do."
A CHP officer backed up right before the train barreled through.
"I was really lucky. I never thought anything like that would ever happen,' said Batti.
Atwater Interim Police Chief Sam Joseph said in the last year, they haven't had any accidents in that intersection and this case is still being investigated.
"The officer taking the report has placed the driver making unsafe turning movements based on the condition of the road."
City Council Member Joe Rivero addressed the dangerous intersection at the council meeting just a day before the accident. He said he saw a truck struggling to make a right turn at the exact same intersection on Sunday and said, "I asked to have our city manager look into having the divider removed or come up with another successful solution. Regrettably, a day and a half later an accident occurs there. Thankfully no one was injured."
"They have to get rid of the center dividers-- it's too high," said Batti.
Steps are already being made to improve the intersection. The middle median has already been removed the scene.
Rivero said he's followed up with the city manager and engineers have been notified to examine the area.
column47: See reverse side for instructions and codes

column11: Train smashes into semi-truck stuck on tracks in Atwater - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
ATWATER, Calif. (KFSN) -- A spectacular crash Tuesday in the North Valley between a speeding freight train and a trailer truck.
According to Atwater police, the crash happened at noon at the Applegate Road rail crossing. Somehow the semi's trailer got tangled up on the tracks.
Traffic started backing up and #abc30insider Anthony Zambrano caught video of the train striking the truck.
As the train barreled down the tracks on a collision course an officer quickly tries to get out of the way. You can see him in the video running in reverse.
The train smashed into the trailer but no one at the scene suffered any injuries.
The intersection remained closed for hours as workers tried to clear the wreck from the tracks and the roadway.
column68: No, no special study block mentioned
column69: A freight train collided with a trailer truck at the Applegate Road rail crossing, causing traffic backup. A police officer was seen running in reverse to avoid the collision, but no injuries occurred. The scene was cleared by workers after the incident.

column11: Family and friends mourn the loss of local foodie - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- Adrian Loza's family says the 29-year-old cook was always there, whether you needed a friend, or a great meal.
On the GoFundMe page they've set up for him, a family member says, "Many knew Adrian for his vibrant personality, his kind heart, and of course, his love of food and cooking."
He died Saturday after being hit by a train in Fresno County. Authorities say he was jogging on the tracks with headphones on. He likely didn't hear or see the train. "Everybody really just loved Adrian," said Fresno Grizzlies General Manager Derek Franks. "He touched a lot of people in what he did, and he'll be missed by many."
He connected to the community through cooking authentic Mexican food at his family's restaurant El Premio Mayor. He also cooked on their taco truck, at events like Gazebo Gardens and the Fresno Grizzlies Taco Truck Throwdown. It was a family affair, but Franks says Adrian was the face of the truck. "He's an easy guy to get behind, an easy guy to vote for based on just his personality and his passion," Franks said.
Franks also said they had tastier tacos than the rest, and that lead Loza and his family to winning the Throwdown twice, in 2012, and 2015. Franks says the Grizzlies have been in touch with Loza's family, who assure them they're keeping their restaurants open. The Grizzlies just hope they can compete again in the sixth Taco Truck Throwdown-- this time, in Loza's honor.
Franks says they are working on ways to team up with other organizations to honor Loza in the near future.
column69: Adrian Loza, a 29-year-old cook, was recognized for his vibrant personality, kindness, and passion for food. He tragically died after being hit by a train on the tracks while jogging with headphones on, likely unaware of the approaching train. Adrian was a significant figure in the Fresno community, known for his culinary skills through his family's restaurant El Premio Mayor and the Grizzlies Taco Truck. His family's restaurants are being kept open, and the Grizzlies are organizing a Taco Truck Throwdown in his honor.

column11: Video may explain fatal Fresno train crash that killed 2 - KBAK
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (AP) A videotape may explain why a van pulled into the path of an Amtrak train in Central California, killing two men.
Officer Axel Reyes of the California Highway Patrol said Thursday that investigators are asking Amtrak for video taken from a camera mounted on the train. Reyes says it appears the van's driver on Wednesday went around crossing arms 18 miles south of Fresno, where the train broadsided the van.
Authorities identified the van's driver as 29-year-old Nicholas Spurling; the passenger was 47-year-old Michael Reyna. Both men were from Fresno.
Amtrak spokeswoman Vernae Graham says that locomotives have cameras, but she could not confirm that a video of the crash exists.
The train left Sacramento and was headed to Bakersfield; authorities say no passengers were injured.
column70: Officer Axel Reyes - California Highway Patrol

column11: Victims ID'd in fatal Fresno County crash involving an Amtrak train and a van - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- Victims ID'd in fatal Fresno County crash involving an Amtrak train and a van
The men who died in crash involving an Amtrak train and a van in Fresno County have been identified by the California Highway Patrol.
Nicholas Spurling, 29, and 47-year-old Michael Reyna. Both men were from Fresno. Spurling was driving the van which the CHP says belonged to Bethesda Lutheran Communities in Fresno. An organization that provides services to people with intellectual and developmental disabilities Investigators say the railroad crossing arms were down, but the van ran through them and onto the tracks.
A statement released by Bethesda Lutheran Communities says in part: "Our prayers and deepest condolences go out to both families and to those that knew Michael and Nicholas. Bethesda has deployed staff ministry consultants to be available to support anyone at the Fresno program or throughout the organization who requires comfort."

column11: Fresno woman dies from injures after being clipped by an Amtrak train - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- A woman clipped by an Amtrak train near Clinton and Maroa has died. It happened at about 12:30 p.m. near Fresno City College.
Witnesses told police the 58-year-old woman was trying to cross the tracks, but she was walking with a cane and not moving fast enough. The train clipped the woman and knocked her to the ground.
Investigators say the woman suffered a fractured forearm, a broken leg and internal injuries. The woman was taken to Community Regional Medical Center where she died from her injuries.

column11: Train crashes into car with woman inside in Selma - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
SELMA, Calif. (KFSN) -- A woman escaped any serious injuries on Sunday after her car was hit by a train while she was still inside.
Selma police say the woman was crossing the railroad tracks at Highland Avenue and Golden State Boulevard around 6 p.m. She had driven past the crossing arms as they started coming down. But instead of backing up, police say she panicked and drove forward, trying to make a U-turn.
The woman couldn't get out of the way in time, and the train collided with her car. Luckily, she didn't suffer any injuries but was taken to a local hospital as a precaution.
column24: Highland Avenue and Golden State Boulevard

column11: NTSB: Truck involved in SoCal train crash not stuck on tracks - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
OXNARD, Calif. -- National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed.
"Our information is the collision occurred about 80 feet down the railroad track toward Oxnard. It had to travel there somehow. It was not stuck, bottomed out on the track or something like that, it had actually traveled down the railroad track itself," said Robert Sumwalt with the National Transportation Safety Board.
About 2,100 crossing accident occur each year, but Tuesday's derailment drew NTSB attention because the truck was found having driven down the tracks. Investigators are expected to remain on scene for five to seven days.
"Our objective is to collect perishable evidence," Sumwalt added. "We are not here to speculate. We never speculate at the NTSB. We're not here on scene to determine the cause of the accident. We're not here on scene to analyze. I know everybody wants to know what happened, and we will determine that, but our goal here is to collect that information that will go away with the passage of time."
As part of the investigation, NTSB plans to do a sight distance test, which means they will set up a mock situation to see how far down the track each person could actually see from both the train and pickup truck.
The NTSB is also looking at video and data equipment on the train that should reveal the moments before the crash.
PHOTOS: Metrolink commuter train derails in Oxnard
Jose Alejandro Sanchez Ramirez, 55, of Yuma, Arizona, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of felony hit-and-run after a Metrolink train headed toward Los Angeles struck his large pickup truck, which was hauling a trailer, on the tracks in Oxnard. He was scheduled to be arraigned Thursday.
Information from the control cab showed the train engineer managed to hit the brakes early, but could not avoid the crash.
Ramirez's lawyer Ron Bamieh called the collision an "accident." Ramirez was driving his company's truck and trailer. He has been employed by the same produce trucking company, The Grower's Company, Inc., for 12 years.
"The arrest of Mr. Ramirez is the unfortunate result of law enforcement attempting to cast blame on a man who was caught in a tragic situation with no way to stop the oncoming tragedy. He does not know how or why the truck he was driving stopped on the tracks, and wishes there was something he could have done to prevent this accident," Bamieh said.
Bamieh added that his office's investigation showed that Ramirez's truck did become "entangled and unable to move off the railroad tracks. The truck and the trailer were somehow stuck."
About 50 people were on board. Twenty-eight people were taken to a hospital, including four in critical condition. No fatalities were reported.
On Wednesday, clean-up efforts continued. All derailed cars had been removed from scene. Track repairs and crossing light and arm function checks were ongoing. Authorities were hoping to get the site cleaned up by the end of the day.
Commuting around the area
Delays were expected for commuters traveling near the crash area.
Metrolink riders for Ventura County Line Trains 102, 104 and 106 will be bused around the crash site between the Camarillo, Oxnard or Ventura-East stations and the Moorpark station. Regularly scheduled service resumes for passengers traveling between Los Angeles Union Station and Moorpark station.
VIDEO: Metrolink commuters to be bused around Oxnard train crash site
Amtrak trains, which were suspended in the area on Tuesday, was also expected to resume limited service between Los Angeles and San Luis Obispo. The changes impact Pacific Surfliner and Coast Starlight trains 11 and 14.
Oxnard drivers are urged to avoid the derailment site, located at 5th Street and Rice Avenue, which is expected to stay closed until at least 8 a.m.

column11: Wife of truck driver in Metrolink crash says he was grieving for child - Los Angeles Times
column12:
Wife of truck driver in Metrolink crash says he was grieving for child
- Share via
The wife of the driver who was arrested after his truck was hit by a Metrolink train, which then derailed, defended her husband and said the couple was grieving over the recent death of their daughter.
Lucila Sanchez said her husband, Jose Alejandro Sanchez-Ramirez, 54, of Yuma, Ariz., didn’t want to go to California and begged his employer to stay in Arizona. The couple’s 29-year-old daughter died in July of cancer. They also have a son.
“He said, ‘I don’t want to go,’ ” she said in an interview Tuesday with the L.A. Times. But Sanchez-Ramirez, a mechanic for 12 years with a harvesting company, headed to a job site in Oxnard early Tuesday, where the fiery collision occurred.
On Wednesday, his attorney said he didn’t think Sanchez-Ramirez’s grief played a role in the crash and was not a factor in his driving.
His wife described Tuesday’s events this way: His truck unexpectedly stalled on the tracks. He noticed the train was fast approaching and tried to restart the engine. But his attempts were unsuccessful, so he jumped out of his truck.
But investigators with the National Transportation Safety Board say it appeared his truck was not stuck and that he had been driving on the tracks for some distance.
Sanchez-Ramirez was taken into custody on suspicion of hit-and-run after being found in a disoriented state wandering more than a mile and a half from the scene of the train derailment, said Jason Benites, assistant chief of the Oxnard Police Department.
Police have held him on suspicion of hit-and-run involving multiple people.
“It’s not his fault,” Lucila Sanchez insisted.
His attorney Ron Bamieh said Wednesday the crash was an accident.
Sanchez-Ramirez was not familiar with Oxnard, so he went to the area to check it out before a meeting Wednesday, he said.
Working off a printed Google map, he “mis-perceived the tracks to be the road” and became entangled, his attorney said.
As the train approached, Sanchez-Ramirez hit his high beams to get the train’s attention and even tried to push his 2005 Ford F-450 off the tracks, his attorney said. Unable to find a way to move his truck, “he was then forced to flee to save his own life,” he said.
After the crash, Lucila Sanchez said her husband called their son. Immediately after hearing about the crash, his family left their home in Arizona and made it to Oxnard by morning, she said.
She wasn’t sure if or when he would be released from police custody.
“He is tense,” she said Tuesday. “He is nervous.”
After the arrest, Bamieh said he met with Sanchez-Ramirez and that, who instead of asking about his case, he was focused on the passengers and their injuries.
His attorney described him as a good, hard-working man. The Arizona resident owns a home in Yuma.
After his daughter died of cancer, he and his wife had been helping their son-in-law take care of her children, his attorney said.
Sanchez-Ramirez was working with the Growers Co. in Somerton, Ariz. A statement from the company, where he has worked for 12 years, said he was a good employee and a good family man who posed no risk or danger to the community.
Sanchez-Ramirez, who has a valid Arizona commercial license, told police his pickup truck and trailer got “stuck” at an Oxnard railroad crossing moments before the explosive crash.
There were no fatalities in the 5:46 a.m. derailment, but 28 of the 50 people involved in the crash were rushed to hospitals with injuries such as broken limbs, head trauma and back and neck pain, according to emergency crews.
Arizona criminal records show that Sanchez-Ramirez pleaded guilty on Dec. 2, 1998, to a host of violations in a single case, including driving with a blood alcohol content above 0.08%, the legal limit in the state; failure to obey a police officer; having liquor with a minor on the premises and having no insurance.
In 2004, Sanchez-Ramirez was convicted of a local driving infraction in Yuma, and in 2007 he was cited for failure to obey a traffic-control device.
For breaking news in California, follow @VeronicaRochaLA

column11: Pedestrian Killed After Being Hit By Train In Fresno - KMPH
GoFundMe identifies two people killed after car crashes into train in Wasco - KBAK
column12:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — UPDATED (4/23/2024, 5 P.M.):
The other two people who were killed in Sunday's fatal Wasco train crash have been identified by friends and family in a GoFundMe.
Eric and Sebastian Tellez were killed early Sunday morning on Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 when CHP said the driver, Mckinley Jordan Toliver, 19,hit the railroad crossing arm and then hit the train. Their vehicle rolled over.
The GoFundMe for Eric and Sebastian Tellez can be found HERE.
---------------
UPDATED (12:55 P.M.): Three men died after one of the men, identified as a 19-year-old man, was driving a car when he hit the railroad crossing arm and struck a train passing by early Sunday morning.
The California Highway Patrol said on April 21, 2024, at around 3:03 a.m., officers received a call from the Wasco Police Department and were called to Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 for a crash involving a vehicle and train.
CHP said a preliminary investigation found that a 19-year-old man, identified as Mckinley Jordan Toliver, was driving a 2021 Honda, traveling westbound on Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 towards the railroad tracks/train, at an undetermined rate of speed.
The train was traveling northbound on the tracks ahead of the Honda.
CHP said for reasons still under investigation, the driver hit the railroad crossing arm, and then hit the train. The Honda rolled over and traveled out of control in a northerly direction.
As a result of this crash, the driver and his two passengers, one identified as a 27-year-old man and the other also as a man, died.
An Eyewitness News crew saw a memorial made for the three men involved in the crash.
According to a photo frame, a candlelight vigil was held the same day.
The use of alcohol and/or drugs as a factor in this crash is under investigation, according to CHP.
CHP said any witnesses with information are asked to call the California Highway Patrol, Bakersfield Area at (661)396-6600.

column11: Man arrested for consuming severed leg at fatal train accident scene in US - Times of India
column12:
NEW DELHI: A tragic
train accident in Wasco, California, took a horrifying twist as a man was arrested for consuming the severed leg of a pedestrian who had been fatally struck by the train. The Kern County Sheriff's Office has launched an investigation into the disturbing incident, which has left the community in disbelief.
The incident occurred at the local Amtrak station in Wasco, situated approximately 25 miles northwest of Bakersfield. According to authorities, a pedestrian was struck by a passing train, resulting in their untimely death and the severing of one of their legs.
Eyewitnesses were left stunned as they watched the perpetrator, identified as 27-year-old Resendo Tellez, brazenly approach the scene of the accident. In wild footage captured by onlookers, Tellez can be seen closely inspecting the severed leg, even appearing to sniff it, before callously absconding with the gruesome evidence.
Despite the presence of law enforcement officers and bewildered bystanders, Tellez showed no signs of remorse or concern. He reportedly waved casually at cameras as he made his escape, swinging the severed leg with nonchalance.
Tellez was swiftly apprehended by authorities and now faces multiple charges, including the theft of evidence from the accident scene, in addition to outstanding warrants. Meanwhile, the identity of the victim remains undisclosed, pending notification of their next of kin.
The Kern County Sheriff's Office is continuing its investigation into the tragic incident, grappling with the disturbing circumstances surrounding the fatal train accident and the bizarre actions of the perpetrator. The community of Wasco is left reeling from the shock of such a gruesome and unsettling event, as they grapple with the aftermath of the tragedy.

column11: Coroner identifies Corona woman struck, killed by train in Delano - KBAK
column12:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KBAK/FOX58) — The Kern County Coroner's Office identified a woman struck and killed by a train in Delano on Sept. 21 as Cassandra Regina Holguin, 27, of Corona, Calif.
The incident happened at around 9:49 a.m. in the 2200 block of High Street in Delano when Holguin was struck by a Union Pacific train. She died at the scene, said the coroner.
Her cause of death was determined to be multiple blunt force injuries and the manner was an accident, said officials.
The Union Pacific Railroad Police investigated the incident.

column11: Driver killed when he tried to beat train in Shafter: CHP - KBAK
column12:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — The California Highway Patrol and Kern County Fire Department responded to a collision Thursday involving a train and driver near Shafter.
Around 4:43 p.m., CHP officers responded to Poplar Avenue at Highway 43.
Upon arrival, officers found a man's body inside a vehicle.
The investigation revealed that the man was driving his vehicle northbound on Poplar Avenue when it appeared that he attempted to beat a train on the tracks at Highway 43, said a CHP official.
The man died from his injuries at the crash site. It is unknown if drugs or alcohol were factors in the crash.
Poplar Avenue at Highway 43 was closed for around 2 hours for the investigation.
KCFD said there were approximately 60 passengers, not including train personnel on board.
One passenger and one train employee were assessed, and both denied treatment.
CHP and Shafter PD closed the roads, and the railroad company was contacted to shut down all rail traffic.
About an hour later firefighters returned to the scene.
The coroner had completed their on-scene investigations and firefighters could begin recovery efforts.
The vehicle was stabilized with "Rescue 42’s" and "Hurst" equipment from their fire engines were used to extricate the deceased victim from the vehicle.

column11: [01-19-2023] Kern County, CA – Train and Car Crash in Shafter Fatally Struck One Person - Arash Law
column12:
One person was killed following a train crash in Shafter on Thursday afternoon, January 19, 2023.
According to reports, the collision occurred around 4:43 p.m. near Madera and Poplar avenues.
Authorities stated that a vehicle on the track collided with the train while moving from Bakersfield to Oakland.
As a result, the lone passenger in the car died at the scene.
Meanwhile, the Amtrak train’s 73 passengers and staff were uninjured.
According to the Amtrak representative, Amtrak is investigating local law enforcement.
Officials advised motorists to avoid the area.
Fatal Train Crash Statistics
According to the National Transportation Safety Board, pedestrians die in railway accidents more often than in collisions with cars. Faulty warning systems, outdated or absent safety equipment, and dangerous crossings cause the most deadly train accidents.
About every two hours, a train collides with someone or a car. Each year, more than a thousand people are killed in train accidents. There were about 2,300 injuries and 600 fatalities as a result.
Trains are the most effective form of transportation. The skills of the conductors and how frequently repairs are made are factors that affect employee and passenger safety. Passengers are at risk due to their negligence or inadequate shortcuts.
Over 7,200 people have died in US train accidents since 1997. Trains colliding with pedestrians on American railroads are currently the leading cause of fatalities, outpacing all other factors.
Derailments, worn-out tracks, contempt for safety regulations, lax security, and other factors are typically to blame for railway accidents.
Reliable Train Accident Lawyers in Shafter
Most people have taken the subway or another type of public transit at some point. Accidents can still happen even if this is a generally safe and effective means of transportation.
The chance of injury or death in a railway accident is smaller than for many other modes of transportation, yet it is nevertheless present. You might be entitled to compensation if you or a loved one is hurt in a railway accident.

column11: 1 dead, 3 injured after vehicle hit by Amtrak train in Shafter - KBAK
column12:
SHAFTER, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — UPDATE (8:30 p.m.)
Three passengers were minorly injured in the Amtrak crash with a vehicle at Sante Fe Way between Orange and Burbank streets, according to the Kern County Fire Department.
Just after 2 p.m. firefighters responded to the Shafter cross streets regarding a report of a passenger vehicle and a passenger train collision.
Upon arrival, firefighters saw a vehicle wedged under the train, fully engulfed in flames. The fire was heading toward the passenger areas of the train, said the department.
A total of 137 passengers were evacuated safely and firefighters began searching extensively throughout the train for anyone left on the train. Everyone was confirmed to be out of the train.
Twelve people required some medical assessment but only three were confirmed for minor injuries. No passengers were sent to the hospital.
Fire officials said the person that died inside the vehicle was a solo occupant.
The Kern County Sheriff's Office, Shafter PD, CHP andBNSF (Bakersfield Terminal) police assisted.
---
A vehicle struck by an Amtrak train in Shafter Friday afternoon killed a person, according to the Kern County Fire Department.
At approximately 2:08 p.m. a rescue incident was reported at Sante Fe Way and Orange Street on Pulse Point.
Emergency personnel and Shafter police arrived and found a vehicle on the tracks, engulfed after it was struck by the Amtrak train.
Over 100 passengers were on the train during the crash but no other injuries were reported. The passengers were taken off the train after the crash.
The identity of the person killed is pending.
Traffic closed in both directions on Sante Fe Way, between Orange and Burbank streets.Avoid the area if possible.
This story is developing and will be updated once more information is provided.

column11: One confirmed dead after train vs. vehicle in Wasco - KBAK
column12:
WASCO, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — UPDATE: 4:15 PM: The Kern County Fire Department and Kern County Sheriff's Deputies from the Wasco Substation responded to the scene of a train vs. vehicle collision in the area of 6th and G Streets in Wasco.
When deputies arrived, they discovered a vehicle on the railway fully engulfed. A person was found dead in the vehicle.

column11: Richland School District identifies boy killed by train - KBAK
column12:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — Richland School District announced the death of one of its students Wednesday afternoon in a letter to parents.
Nathaniel A. Bojorquez was struck and killed by a train Tuesday on Shafter Avenue just north of Highway 43.
Bojorquez was an eighth-grade student, described as a kind boy who loved to play video games and listen to music.

column11: Amtrak train strikes truck in Richmond, no injuries reported - ABC7 San Francisco
column12:
RICHMOND, Calif. -- An Amtrak train struck a truck in Richmond Tuesday morning, according to police.
Train No. 711, which runs from Bakersfield to Oakland, struck the vehicle around 10:30 a.m. in the vicinity of Cutting and Carlson boulevards, according to Amtrak spokeswoman Vernae Graham.
No injuries were reported by anyone on the train or in the truck, Graham said.
"At this point we're trying to do a bus bridge, trying to secure alternate transportation," Graham said. "We do have mutual aid from BART at Richmond."
Cutting Boulevard has been closed because of the crash, police said around 11 a.m. They expect the roadway to remain closed into the early afternoon hours.
Carlson Boulevard is unaffected, according to police.

column11: Man hit and killed by train in Hanford, police say - ABC30 Fresno
column12:
HANFORD, Calif. (KFSN) -- The Hanford Police Department says the man hit by a train Saturday died at the scene.
An Amtrak train was traveling from Oakland to Bakersfield around 4:30 p.m. Saturday.
Officers say the man was on the tracks when he was hit.
The man has not been identified.

column11: Teacher Killed After LIRR Train Strikes Car - Patch
column12:
Crime & Safety
Teacher Killed After LIRR Train Strikes Car
A fundraiser is collecting donations for the Long Island woman's funeral service. About $12,000 has been raised in one day.
A teacher has been identified as the person who was killed after her car veered onto train tracks and was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train early Saturday in East Northport. Elizabeth Gallagher, 29, of Centereach, struck a guardrail, which caused her vehicle to go down an embankment and get struck by an eastbound train at about 2:10 a.m., the New York Post reported.
Gallagher, who was discovered dead outside of her vehicle, would have turned 30 March 6.
A former middle school teacher in the Roosevelt School District, according to the Post, Gallagher was on her way home from her second job at a restaurant when the high winds caused her car to veer off the road, the New York Daily News reported.

A fundraiser collecting donations for Gallagher's funeral service raised about $12,000 in one day.
On the donation page, one person commented, "This is truly crushing. My thoughts and prayers go out to you all. She was a beautiful soul. Going to miss all her upbeat facebook posts!"
Find out what's happening in Northportfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Another wrote, "You were a true ray of sunshine in my life. I'm forever grateful to have the memories I have growing up with you. Still can't believe it. My deepest condolences to your family."

column11: [Withdrawn] Buffer stop collision at Kings Cross - GOV.UK
column12:
Buffer stop collision at Kings Cross
Train collided with buffer stops at Kings Cross station, London, 15 August 2017.
At 06:23 hrs on Tuesday 15 August 2017 a train arriving from Royston collided with the buffer stops in platform 9 at Kings Cross station, while travelling at about 4 mph (6 km/h). Three passengers were slightly hurt, and there was minor damage to the train and the buffer stop equipment.
We have undertaken a preliminary examination of the circumstances surrounding this accident. Having assessed the evidence which has been gathered to date, we have decided to publish a safety digest.

column11: Amtrak train collides with forklift - Hanford Sentinel
column12:
An Amtrak train traveling from Corcoran to Hanford Tuesday morning struck a large commercial forklift that was stalled on the railroad crossing at Lansing Avenue in Kings County, according to officials.
There were reportedly 53 passengers on board the train at the time of the accident. Kings County Fire Department Battalion Chief Rick Smith said no one was injured. He said one person complained of minor injuries, but refused medical treatment.
California Highway Patrol Public Information Officer Adam Barresi said the driver of the forklift was traveling eastbound on Lansing Avenue around 8:30 a.m. when the forklift suddenly stalled on the tracks. He said the driver was unable to get the vehicle to restart.
Barresi said when the northbound train began approaching and the crossing arms started to come down, the driver then jumped off the forklift and ran.
The train was delayed for about two hours.
“The train was held for an investigation then released and allowed to proceed on its way at approximately 10:30 a.m.,” Craig Schulz, Amtrak spokesman, said.
The reporter can be reached at 583-2427 or swilliams@HanfordSentinel.com. Follow her on Twitter at ShannonW_HS.

column11: Passenger suffers serious injuries after falling between platform and moving train as it left Charing Cross - Daily Mail
column12:
Woman suffers serious injuries after falling between platform and moving train at Charing Cross
- Incident occurred at 10.30pm on Saturday night as a Kent service left the platform at Charing Cross
A woman suffered serious injuries after falling between the platform and a moving train at Charing Cross station last night.
The woman, said to be in her thirties and hailing from Kent, was taken to hospital where she is being treated for her injuries, including to one of her legs.
The incident is not being treated as suspicious and the victim is in a stable condition, British Transport Police confirmed.
Tragic: The accident occurred just after 10.30pm as the Dartford-bound train left the platform
As the train began to leave the platform at Charing Cross station the woman somehow fell in the gap between it and the platform.
A British Transport Police (BTP) spokesman said: 'BTP officers were called to Charing Cross rail station on Saturday, 24 November, after a woman fell between a train and the platform as the service had begun to move away.
'London Ambulance Service medics also attended and the woman, aged in her thirties and from Kent, was taken to King's College Hospital with serious injuries, including to one of her legs.
'She currently remains in hospital and is described as being in a stable condition.
Accident: Emergency staff rush to the woman's aid after she fell between the train and the platform at Charing Cross
Stable condition: Ambulance staff are caring for the victim, who is being treated for serious injuries at Kings College Hospital in the capital
'The incident was reported to BTP at 10.32pm. Having spoken to witnesses and viewed CCTV, officers are currently treating the incident as non-suspicious and accidental, although enquiries will be made to establish the full circumstances.'
The train involved was the 22:26 Charing Cross to Dartford service. The tracks were handed back to Network Rail at 11.27pm.
Anyone who witnessed the incident should contact BTP on Freefone 0800 40 50 40 quoting reference 626 of 24 November.
